page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 12 August To M
r
Secretary
It maye please yo
r
H. there came letters
this daye to
e
Councell
heere, from the Depu-
ties in
England,
who desire to be informed
of all
e forces that can be made in these Pro-
vinces: wherof
e collection will be made, and
sent unto them. In
e meane season it should
seeme
at they have reported to her
Ma
tie
of
seven or eight thousand that may be brought
into
e field, and their Garrisons left provi-
ded. But I have urged them heere to spe-
cifie
e nombers and places where they are:
and by any reckning
at they can make, they
will hardly reache to 4000 in all. There
are at this present w
t
Count Maurice
about
Gorchum
2500 w
t
e most: of w
ch
there are
Inglishe, 200 from
Ostend,
240 from
Flushing,
160 from
e
Brill,
and 150 from
Berghen,
besides two Cornets of horse of my
L. Willughby
and
S
r
William Russel
, which are merve-
lously weakned w
t
these late services. The
rest, I am well assured, will hardly make
up 1500. Whiche is very neere half
e nomber
at can be drawen to service in these contreis.
For
e rest in effect are all w
t
Count Willi
a
in
Frieseland,
and in
Schinckes
sconces, whiche
will scarely be founde by just account 2000.
The Enemie about
Hoesden
increa-
seth his forces daily,
and
w
ch
are not thought at
this p
nt
to be so fewe as 10000 foote, and
3000 horse. Howbeit there is nothing yet
attempted, against
e towne.
fol.80v
The Count intendeth to surprise a fort, whiche
the Enemie hath over against
Hemart,
and
is thought to be weake, and slenderly garded.
If it take good effect, it will make very muche
for
e savegard of
Holland.
Mons
r
de la Thuillerie
e Frenche kinges Embassado
r
hat had his audience heere: and his request is
to have
at promise, w
ch
was made to
Mons
r
du Fay
, for
e loane of 30000 crownes, uppon
condition
that it were imploied to
e levieng of men in
Germany,
and w
t
in
e space of 6 monethes, to
be enlarged to
e summe of 50000 crownes, w
t
out condition of time, or prescription of the
maner howe it should be imploied. What
answear will be made, I can not yet under
tand. I am given to under
stand, that there is a Replie intended, and
as it is thought, already begonne by
Barne-
velt
and
Aersens
against my
L. Willughby
As touching those Articles to w
ch
yo
r
H hath so
long expected
e
Generall states
resoluc
o
n,
I thinke this day or to morowe they send
their letters and answear to her Ma
tie
, and,
as it seemeth,
thos
when their letters are gone,
and not before, it will be imparted unto
me. By this meanes, I can not doe
at ser-
vice, whiche is requisit, in dealing privatly
heere, or in writing to yo
r
H. And if
ei
shall w
t
hold it from me in
at order, in my
next I will advertise yo
w
of it, and if
yo
w
shall judge it behoofull to taxe, in presence
fol.81r
of their Deputies, their proposterous procee-
ding, it may happely effect some good for
hereafter.
At this Instant yo
r
H. of
e 2 and of
e 3
of this [p
nt
]
w
t
e inclosed advertisments from
Diepe,
are
come to my handes: for w
ch
I yeld yo
r
H. most
h
u
ble thankes. For I am c
o
monly advertised ne-
ther truly, nor in time of suche occurrences: w
ch
notw
t
standing steede me very muche for my better
both credit and direction in many thinges heere,
at
tend to
e furtherance of my service. Not-
w
t
stand
e prowd cariage of
[late] both of
them heere, and also there
if those smalle helpes
at this place doth affourd,
doe not too muche deceave me, yo
r
H. neede not to
suspect any wrong measure at their handes. For
I can see no kinde of likelihood of any so great
alienation in them. But doutles
at w
ch
they have
alwaies c
o
ceaved, doth nowe breake out to open
declaration, uppon this comfortles returne from
o
r
Portugall
service.
w
ch
is to speak in
plaine tearmes
to witte or
ei thinke
her Ma
tie
will not, nor c
a
not if she wold
w
t
any safetie to
her self ab
a
d
o
these
c
o
treis. And whether
they be not grow
e
to this
imaginati
o
,
at
to proceede
stoutly
w
t
her Ma
tie
and to
put her in feare of dea-
ling w
t
e Ennemie,
if they
shall
may
not be
assisted as they wold
is the best course
at they c
a
take,
I leave
e judgem
t
thereof to yo
r
H.
but being
It may be happely in
my next I shall deliver
yo
r
H a second
cause
yo
w
[some friller]
of this their
unaccustomed
insolence.
The affecti
o
w
ch
they bear to the
Ther is no dout but they doe affect
e
newe
Frenche K
but for certaine
as I
a
persuaded is more in shewe then in
hart, and more to drawe her Ma
tie
forward, then
by offering s
o
occasi
o
of fear
of [.], as
no doubt
they
are ready
wold to
ffer] to doe
it
e like
to any
other Prince,
at would feede their humo
r
s w
t
e
w
t
whome they
might serve to
have any
colour
good coulo
r
of
i
differ
e
ce to seeme [.]
to fall in treaty.
and all
best hope of assistance. And whether suche cogita-
c
o
ns proceede not wholy of a special defect and
weaknes in their judgements, I leave
e c
e
sur
to yo
r
H.
and
thus I
take my h
u
ble leave &c.
